The formality of paying for and obtaining tickets on each occasion when a car uses the Manama-Muharraq Cause way results in delay which, in the case of members of the public, does not matter very much. In the case of R # A»F. cars, vans or lorries, however, a delay of a few minutes might, in certain circumstances, have serious consequences. 2m I suggest that, if the Bahrain authorities concerned see no objection, a monthly fee might be charged for each vehicle using the Causeway. At the beginning of each month the Air Liaison Officer would send a description of the vehicles in respect of which a monthly fee was being paid, and these vehicles would display prominently a roundel bearing the R*A.F. colours. Vehicles displaying this roundel would then be allowed past the barriers at the entrances to the Causeway without being detained. 3* I understand that a somewhat similar arrangement was made with the Defence Officer, and I shall be grateful if the same facilities can be extended to the R.A.F. During the recent visit to Bahrain of certain senior R.A.F. officers the car in which they were driving from Muharraq to Manama was delayed for some minutes at the barrier at the entrance to the Cause way while tickets were produced and paid for. In order to prevent the recurrence of delays of this <*/ nature Squadron Leader^Aggapeyef was directed to approach me with the request that R.A.F. cars might be allowed past the barrier without having to stop while tickets were purchased. Free passes are not granted for use of the Causeway, but I wrote to the Adviser, Bahrain Government, asking whether monthly fees could be charged for each R .A.F. vehicle using the Causeway. I enclose for your information a copy of my letter to the Adviser No.C/560 dated 30th April 1942 and of his reply dated 5th May 1942 (with enclos ure in original). 2. titleInfo.title: ‘File 7/28 Payment of toll gate fees by R.A.F.’

physicalDescription.extent: The file’s contents are arranged in chronological order, from the earliest item at the front to the latest at the end. Circled index numbers written using blue/red crayon can also be found in throughout the file, and refer to the page of office notes at the end of the file (folio 4).

Foliation: The foliation sequence begins on the front cover and ends on the back cover; these numbers are written in pencil, and can be found in the top right corner of the recto side of each folio. The following foliation anomalies occur: 1, 1A, and 1B.

mods.abstract: The contents of the file relate to a proposal (folio 1B) made by the Political Agent at Bahrain (Edward Birkbeck Wakefield) to the Adviser to the Bahrain Government (Charles Dalrymple Belgrave) that a monthly fee be paid by the RAF to allow their vehicles to cross the Manama-Muharraq causeway, in place of the existing charges applied to each individual vehicle on crossing, which, the Agent says, causes unnecessary delays.
